unnormalised: **Tech Glitch Briefly Turns India Back to 1947; Twitter Explodes**
normalised: **Tech Glitch Briefly Turns India Back to nineteen forty seven; Twitter Explodes**

unnormalised: In a stunning, albeit temporary, hiccup that could only happen in the digital age, India briefly experienced a time warp this morning. For approximately 1 hour 34 minutes, starting at 9:17 AM IST, a widespread tech glitch caused numerous digital platforms to display dates as 15/08/1947. Yes, you read that right – Independence Day. The jokes, of course, wrote themselves.
normalised: In a stunning, albeit temporary, hiccup that could only happen in the digital age, India briefly experienced a time warp this morning. For approximately one hour thirty four minutes, starting at nine seventeen A.M. I.S.T., a widespread tech glitch caused numerous digital platforms to display dates as fifteenth august nineteen forty seven. Yes, you read that right – Independence Day. The jokes, of course, wrote themselves.

unnormalised: Social media erupted in a frenzy. #BackTo1947 trended on Twitter as users shared screenshots of bank balances dated to pre-independence times (presumably showing zero rupees, a slight exaggeration), and bewildered news articles proudly announcing India's freedom from British rule. One user hilariously quipped, "My laptop thinks Netaji is still a hot topic! It's stuck on 18/08/1945 for Pete's sake!"
normalised: Social media erupted in a frenzy. hash Back To nineteen forty seven trended on Twitter as users shared screenshots of bank balances dated to pre-independence times (presumably showing zero rupees, a slight exaggeration), and bewildered news articles proudly announcing India's freedom from British rule. One user hilariously quipped, "My laptop thinks Netaji is still a hot topic! It's stuck on eighteenth august nineteen forty five for Pete's sake!"

unnormalised: The chaos wasn't limited to social media. Several online payment gateways reportedly went haywire, leading to concerns about transactions being "time-travelled" into oblivion. Imagine buying a samosa for ₹10 only to have your account debited sometime before Gandhi even started his Salt March! Luckily, financial institutions swiftly assured customers that all transactions were secure (probably).
normalised: The chaos wasn't limited to social media. Several online payment gateways reportedly went haywire, leading to concerns about transactions being "time-travelled" into oblivion. Imagine buying a samosa for rupee ten only to have your account debited sometime before Gandhi even started his Salt March! unnormalised: According to sources at the Ministry of Time-Related Glitches (yes, we made that up, but honestly, it feels necessary), the issue stemmed from a "minor date formatting error" during a server update. "A tiny gremlin got into the system," a spokesperson vaguely explained, "and briefly convinced our servers that it was still the Raj."
normalised: According to sources at the Ministry of Time-Related Glitches (yes, we made that up, but honestly, it feels necessary), the issue stemmed from a "minor date formatting error" during a server update. "A tiny gremlin got into the system," a spokesperson vaguely explained, "and briefly convinced our servers that it was still the Raj."

unnormalised: The glitch was eventually resolved at 11:01 AM, leaving behind a trail of bewildered citizens and a whole lot of comedic gold. Experts are now advising users to, uh, maybe double-check their bank statements. And perhaps take a moment to appreciate the relative stability of the present, even with all its dating apps and traffic jams.
normalised: The glitch was eventually resolved at eleven zero one A.M., leaving behind a trail of bewildered citizens and a whole lot of comedic gold. Experts are now advising users to, uh, maybe double-check their bank statements. And perhaps take a moment to appreciate the relative stability of the present, even with all its dating apps and traffic jams.

unnormalised: So, there you have it. A brief moment where India collectively travelled back in time, all thanks to a rogue semicolon or something equally trivial. Just another day in the always-entertaining saga of technology and Indian reality. Guess we can all prepone our Independence day celebrations for next year in case this happens again! And let’s be honest, who wouldn’t want a second chance at eating those jalebis?
